description.plain:
West Coast Legend from Philadelphia. He is one half of the rap duo Tha Dogg Pound, along with Daz Dillinger.

In 1992, at age 19, Kurupt signed to Death Row Records, newly formed by music manager Suge Knight and Dr. Dre, the rapper and music producer who had just left the rap group N.W.A and its Ruthless Records. At Death Row, Kurupt joined a roster of artists—including Daz Dillinger, The Lady of Rage, Snoop Dogg, Nate Dogg, and RBX—who entered the public eye by their features on Dr. Dre’s debut solo album The Chronic. Kurupt and Daz soon teamed as a rap duo, Tha Dogg Pound, featured on Snoop Dogg’s debut solo album, Doggystyle, in the song For All My Niggaz & Bitches.

By 1996, the rap genre’s East Coast–West Coast rivalry was escalating, spurred on by Death Row’s CEO Suge and by rapper 2Pac, new to the label, who believed that a Bad Boy Entertainment circle, in their hometown New York City, had fostered his November 1994 shooting there. Tha Dogg Pound released the single New York, New York featuring Snoop Dogg, slighting the city. The duo’s debut album, Dogg Food, produced by Daz and mixed by Dre, drew favorable reviews and good sales.

description.plain: The DJ Battlecat-produced first single from Kurupt’s 1998 post-Death Row solo debut album, Kuruption!  The video features appearances from Ice-T, W.C., Warren G, Snoop Dogg, & former Dogg Pound nemesis Dresta.  Noticeably absent is Daz Dillinger.  This may have an intentional omission, as Kurupt was just beginning his solo career and may have wanted to establish his own identity.  But DPG fans need not have worried, as Daz was featured prominently on Kuruption!

description.plain: Produced by Fredwreck, the song is the first track on Kurupt’s third solo album, Space Boogie: Smoke Oddessey.  Featuring a small sample from Dr. Dre’s “Light Speed”, the song is further proof that Nate Dogg improved any track he sang on.

Kurupt’s best selling single on the Streetlights (2010) album. Featuring Problem this mellow beat mixed with that old school west coast flava guarantees success.

Kurupt went on to make a remix known as “I’m Burnt (G-Mix)” Featuring Snoop Dogg and Problem once again

songs.full_title: Ho's a Housewife by Kurupt (Ft. Paul Dombroski)
songs.title: Ho’s a Housewife

description.plain: A song from Kurupt’s debut solo album Kuruption! Dr. Dre liked this song so much that he re-worked it for his album Chronic 2001.  Dre’s version (which also appeared on Kurupt’s sophomore album  Tha Streetz Iz a Mutha) kept the chorus and the first verse (along with some extra bars at the beginning) but also added new production along with verses from Dre and Hittman.

songs.full_title: I Call Shots by Kurupt (Ft. Roscoe)
songs.title: I Call Shots

description.plain: Produced by Organized Noize, this is the first song on Kurupt’s 1999 album Tha Streetz iz a Mutha.  It features a dope verse from Roscoe, Kurupt’s bioogical brother, who was just coming up in the rap game at the time.  Possibly an attempt to do for Roscoe what Jay tried to do for Bleek by featuring him on the first song on his album?

songs.full_title: Ask Yourself a Question by Kurupt (Ft. Dr. Dre)
songs.title: Ask Yourself a Question
songs.title_with_featured: Ask Yourself a Question (Ft. Dr. Dre)

description.plain: Produced by and featuring Dr. Dre, “Ask Yourself a Question” is the twelfth and last track on the first disc of Kurupt’s debut studio album, Kuruption! After the album’s release, Kurupt was so pleased with Dr. Dre’s contribution to the album that he wanted Dre to produce the entirety of his next album. This plan never came to be, although Kurupt was able to land 3 features on Dre’s sophomore album, 2001, the following year.

songs.full_title: This One's for U by Kurupt
songs.title: This One’s for U

description.plain:
The first song from Kurupt’s debut solo album, produced by Studio Ton.

Unlike the majority of the album, it features no other performers, allowing Kurupt to present himself to the world as a solo artist for the first since his debut on Dr. Dre’s The Chronic five years earlier.

songs.full_title: We Can Freak It (NY Remix) by Kurupt (Ft. N.O.R.E. & Stevie J)
songs.title: We Can Freak It (NY Remix)
songs.title_with_featured: We Can Freak It (NY Remix) (Ft. N.O.R.E. & Stevie J)

description.plain: Produced by a very pre-“Love and Hip Hop Atlanta” Stevie J. (who’s voice can be heard throughout the song), the track features a surprising (at the time) combination of Kurupt and N.O.R.E. (who was then known as Noreaga).  Capone-n-Noreaga had recently put out an answer record to the Dogg Pound’s New York, New York record called L.A., L.A.  Part of Kurupt’s solo album Kuruption (East Code disc), this song squashed any beef between the two camps.

songs.full_title: Fresh by Kurupt (Ft. Daz Dillinger)
songs.title: Fresh

description.plain: Possibly the most lyrical Kurupt has ever been, this song is pure bravado and lyrical posturing. There are references in the second verse to The Horsemen (super group consisting of Ras Kass, Killah Priest, Canibus and Kurupt) which makes people think the verse was meant for that project. However, this song came way before they announced the supergroup. Kurupt’s third verse is hip hop at its finest.

songs.full_title: Tha Past by Kurupt (Ft. Dave Hollister)
songs.title: Tha Past

description.plain:
In this song, Kurupt addresses his beef with Daz Dillinger, his former partner-in-rhyme.

While the two rappers had gained notoriety collaborating as Tha Dogg Pound, a rap duo signed to Death Row Records during its early-90s heyday, and become as close as brothers, the two began beefing in 2002 when Kurupt signed a deal to return to Death Row as the label’s Vice President. This move offended Daz, as well as other former Death Row artists affiliated with the Dogg Pound, such as Snoop Dogg and Soopafly, as they still harbored animosity towards label president Suge Knight. A beef between Kurupt and Daz erupted as a result, complete with the requisite dis tracks and public slander.

However, amid all the acrimony, Kurupt still fondly looked back on his days of making music with his buddy Daz. This song chronicles his feelings about being angry with his former colleague and best friend, and the complex dichotomy between their sunny past and their stormy present.

Shortly after this record was released, Kurupt and Daz – at the urging of Snoop Dogg – squashed their beef and returned to making music together. As they continue to produce music as Tha Dogg Pound, this song remains as a reminder of their troubled past.

songs.full_title: I'm Back by Kurupt
songs.title: I’m Back

description.plain:
“I’m Back” was first featured on the soundtrack to Eddie Griffin’s documentary and stand-up comedy film DysFunktional Family. The soundtrack was released through the newly reformed Death Row Records, at the time known as Tha Row Records, in March 2003.

Kurupt would later re-release it on his fourth studio album, Against The Grain, in 2005.

Jimmy Bones

Oh shit, niggas better watch out now

songs.full_title: Gimmewhutchagot by Kurupt (Ft. Barshawn)
songs.title: Gimmewhutchagot

description.plain: A song on the East Coast disc of Kuruption!, it featured one of the most (literally) nausea-inducing videos ever made.  Made on what had to be a very small budget, the camera gets flipped upside down and sideways by Kurupt and his friends throughout the video.  A welcome cameo by Pete Rock on the wheels of steel is also featured in the video.
